questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with a history of local inoperable breast cancer is referred to you for the evaluation of new-onset diplopia. Upon questioning, she admits that diplopia occurs mostly when she attempts to look at objects in the distance and when she attempts to look toward the left side. In addition, she reports having severe headaches and an electric-type discomfort affecting her right deltoid region for approximately 3 weeks. On neurologic examination, she is found to have left abducens (sixth) nerve palsy; the rest of her cranial nerves are intact. She also has mild weakness of the right deltoid and a diminished biceps tendon jerk on the same side. Findings on an MRI of the brain with intravenous contrast are unremarkable. What would be the most likely site for metastasis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Meninges Meningeal carcinomatosis results when malignant cells gain access to the CSF and can disseminate within it. Cells commonly adhere to and affect the neural structures traversing the CSF, such as cranial nerves and peripheral nerve roots. Cells cause dysfunction at multiple sites of the CNS. This patient has a left abducens nerve palsy and a right C5 radiculopathy , making the diagnosis of meningeal carcinomatosis highly likely.

Highyeild:

Cerebral Metastases : Cerebral metastases are the most common brain tumour in adults, making up more than 50% of all brain tumours across all ages. However, they account for only 6% of all paediatric brain tumour cases. Approximately 6% to 14% of patients with cancer develop brain metastases during their illness. The interval or period between the diagnosis of primary cancer and the development of brain metastasis depends on the histology of primary cancer; breast cancer and melanoma generally exhibit the longest interval (mean, 2–3 years) and lung cancer the shortest (mean, 4.5 months)

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with new-onset seizures. Her husband witnessed her have a generalised seizure lasting approximately 1 minute. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes a day for over 40 years. In the past 3 months, she has lost 25 lbs in weight. She appears thin and nervous on examination, but findings on her neurologic examination are otherwise essentially within normal limits. Plain radiographs of the chest obtained in the emergency department show a 4 cm nodule in the upper lobe of her right lung. To exclude cerebral metastasis as a cause of her seizure, what should the next test requested be?

options.label: B
options.text: A CT scan of the brain with intravenous contrast

options.label: C
options.text: A spinal tap to measure opening pressure and obtain CSF for cytology

options.label: D
options.text: An MRI of the brain with intravenous contrast

questions.correct_answer: D. An MRI of the brain with intravenous contrast
questions.explanation:
Solution:

An MRI of the brain with intravenous contrast An adult with new-onset seizures is considered to have a brain tumour until proven otherwise. The best test available to detect metastatic deposits in the brain is the MRI with intravenous contrast. MRI is exquisitely sensitive in diagnosing brain metastasis, sometimes detecting them by the brain oedema they induce even when the lesion itself is too small to be seen.

Highyeild:

Cerebral Metastases : Cerebral metastases are adults' most common brain tumour, making up more than 50% of all brain tumours across all ages. However, they account for only 6% of all paediatric brain tumour cases. Approximately 6% to 14% of patients with cancer develop brain metastases during their illness. The interval or period between the diagnosis of primary cancer and the development of brain metastasis depends on the histology of primary cancer; breast cancer and melanoma generally exhibit the longest interval (mean, 2–3 years) and lung cancer the shortest (mean, 4.5 months)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The EEG may likely show the presence of seizure activity and even localise it to a particular brain region; it will not answer the question of what pathologic process is responsible. Option: B. CT has a poorer sensitivity than MRI for brain tumours. Option: D. In this case, because a mass lesion is expected, performing a spinal tap is relatively contraindicated for fear of inducing uncal herniation in a patient with increased ICP.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is admitted from the emergency department with a history of approximately 2 weeks of headaches. She has a history of breast cancer. Her headache is severe, particularly in the mornings when she wakes up. It is accompanied by occasional vomiting. She says she experiences no focal weakness, numbness, or paraesthesia. On physical examination, she is found to have a mild weakness in her left arm. An MRI of the brain with intravenous contrast reveals the presence of a neoplasm in the right motor cortex responsible for her weakness. If the MRI shows multiple brain metastasis, what treatment should be required besides corticosteroids?

options.label: B
options.text: Craniotomy to resect the lesion responsible for her left arm weakness

options.label: D
options.text: Placement of an Ommaya reservoir for use in treatment by intrathecal chemotherapy

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Whole-brain radiotherapy The optimal management of any intracranial neoplasm includes the use of corticosteroids. These significantly diminish the amount of tumour-induced brain oedema and are remarkably effective in ameliorating symptoms caused by CNS neoplasms. This contrasts head trauma, where the CRASH trial has proven no role of steroids. The current recommendation for treating multiple brain metastasis is treatment with an entire course of fractionated radiation to the whole brain. This is geared to treat all visible lesions within the parenchyma and those that may still be too small to be detected. Intrathecal chemotherapy effectively treats meningeal carcinomatosis, where the primary site of involvement is the meninges and the brain's surface. When administered intrathecally, the two available agents for this treatment modality have poor penetration into deeper brain regions.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents with a several weeks history of headaches and difficulties with speech. A sister who lives with her claims that her language "has recently not made much sense" and that she is confused. Her condition seems to be deteriorating. On neurologic examination, she has moderately severe aphasia, with difficulty understanding language and following commands, and she makes frequent para-phasic errors when she speaks. There are no other motor or sensory deficits. A CT with intravenous contrast reveals the presence of a ring-enhancing mass lesion within the substance of the left temporal lobe. The lesion is approximately 3 cm in greatest diameter, poorly demarcated from the surrounding brain, and surrounded by a moderate amount of cerebral oedema. Findings on routine admission tests, including a chest x-ray and serum chemistry, are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Metastasis to the brain from an occult primary cancer

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glioblastoma multiforme Ring-enhancing lesions within the substance of the temporal lobe confirm gliomas.

Highyeild:

Glioblastoma multiformae is a highly malignant neoplasm arising from glial cells or their precursors within the CNS. It is the most common primary malignancy of the CNS, and its peak incidence is within the fifth to seventh decade of life. Imaging reveals characteristic butterfly appearance. Metastases and gliomas are common tumours within brain substances, appearing as ‘ring-enhancing’ lesions on contrast CT. Surgery is usually life-extending rather than curative. It has an inadequate response to therapy, and death follows in a few months- 2 years from diagnosis.

Very small lesions; exquisitely painful, localised tenderness, cold-sensitive; patients sometimes labelled as malingering. Common in the subungual or volar fingertip.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with a headache and left-sided upper extremity weakness. The MRI findings suggest that this is a glioblastoma multiforme. This is because the tumour exhibits which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: It is well demarcated from surrounding brain tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: It shows a ring enhancement pattern with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic centre.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows an absence of surrounding white-matter oedema.

questions.correct_answer: C. It shows a ring enhancement pattern with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic centre.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It shows a ring enhancement pattern with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic centre. It shows a ring enhancement pattern with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic centre.

Highyeild:

Glioblastoma multiforme grows rapidly, and the tumour often contains a necrotic core that occurs as its growth surpasses its blood supply. Additional features on MRI include irregular shape, poor demarcation from surrounding brain tissue , and a variable amount of surrounding white-matter edema. A WHO grade IV tumour is adults' most commonly encountered primary brain tumour. The presentation can include headaches, seizures, focal deficits, and personality changes. Imaging usually demonstrates a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding oedema and mass effect. Treatment of accessible lesions involves attempted gross total resection, postoperative radiation therapy, and chemotherapy. Temozolomide is the current drug of choice and has been shown to improve both survival and quality of life. Recurrence is common, and repeated surgical resection is often deemed reasonable.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with the complaint of approximately 2 weeks of headache and vomiting. He was seen in the emergency department 1 week earlier with the same complaints. His parents were told the probable cause was a gastrointestinal virus, and the boy was sent home. His symptoms have not improved. On general examination, the child appears somewhat dehydrated and has a dry mouth and sunken eyes. His examination findings are also remarkable for the presence of bilateral papilledema and marked nystagmus. An MRI with intravenous contrast reveals the presence of a 2 cm mass in the posterior fossa. The mass is entirely within the fourth ventricle and appears to be arising from the vermis of the cerebellum. It enhances uniformly with contrast. The lateral and third ventricles are moderately dilated with hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medulloblastoma In the above given case, the MRI shows 2cm small mass which arises from the vermis of the cerebellum and grows entirely within the fourth ventricle. Also the tumor enhances uniformly with contrast. Hence the proabable diagnosis would be Medulloblastoma

Highyeild:

The medulloblastoma (a primitive neuroectodermal tumour or PNET) is a highly aggressive and rapidly growing tumour that most often arises within the cerebellar vermis. It is a small round blue cell tumour. It usually grows locally as a roughly spherical mass to bulge into and obliterate the adjacent fourth ventricle. Ependymoma or choroid plexus papilloma should also be considered in the differential diagnosis.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) are benign nerve sheath tumours, usually presenting with hearing loss, tinnitus and balance problems. Option: B. Craniopharyngioma is histologically benign but may sometimes have local aggressive and relentless behaviour. Option: D. Glioblastoma multiformae is a highly malignant neoplasm arising from glial cells or their precursors within the CNS. It is the most common primary malignancy of the CNS, and its peak incidence is within the fifth to seventh decade of life.

questions.text: A 3- year- old boy complains of headache and vomiting. On examination findings, bilateral papilledema and marked nystagmus are present. MRI reveals the presence of a 3 cm mass in the posterior fossa. The mass is entirely within the fourth ventricle and appears to be arising from the vermis of the cerebellum. It enhances uniformly with contrast. The lateral and third ventricles are moderately dilated with hydrocephalus. He is suspected of having medulloblastoma and was taken to surgery. However, after craniotomy, the pathologist reports that it is a benign lesion; what is that lesion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Choroid plexus papilloma Choroid plexus papillomas are benign tumours of the CNS that arise from the cells that form the choroid plexus. These tumours, including the lateral and fourth ventricles, can be found wherever the choroid plexus is present. They cause symptoms of increased ICP, most commonly by causing massive degrees of hydrocephalus. This can be from two mechanisms— obstruction of normal CSF pathways or production by the tumour of excessive volumes of CSF. (Remember that CSF is produced mainly by the choroid plexus.)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ependymomas are also highly malignant tumours usually found in the fourth ventricle of children. Its precursor cell is the ependymal cell that lines the ventricular system. As medulloblastomas, these tumours are highly aggressive and fast-growing. Contrary to the former, however, ependymomas tend to arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle (the dorsal surface of the brainstem) Option: D. Teratomas consists of different tissues derived from ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm. Immature components are often neuroectodermal or mesenchymal tissue, while more mature tissue is often cystic with epithelial differentiation or consists of smooth muscle, connective tissue or cartilage.

questions.text: A 21-year male was diagnosed to have a craniopharyngioma. He underwent a craniotomy for the resection of his lesion. Twelve hours postoperatively, he developed diuresis of over 500 mL/h. The diagnosis of (DI) was entertained. What laboratory findings are most consistent with the clinical impression?

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased both serum and urine osmolality

options.label: D
options.text: Increased serum osmolality and decreased urine osmolality

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased serum osmolality and decreased urine osmolality
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased serum osmolality and decreased urine osmolality DI is defined by increased diluted urinary output, constant thirst for usually cold water, and high serum osmolality

Highyeild:

The low level of ADH secretion commonly precipitates DI. The clinical presentation does not manifest until over 85% of ADH secretory capacity is damaged. Rarely is it nephrogenic and is caused by a lack of renal response to ADH hormone. The toxic effect of certain drugs or familial X-linked recessive genetic disorders often produces the nephrogenic form. DI is defined by increased diluted urinary output, constant thirst for usually cold water, and high serum osmolality . If it is not properly treated it can lead to extreme dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. The best test is water deprivation for 4 hours while monitoring the urine output and urine and serum osmolality. If urine osmolality remains flat or changes to less than 30 mOsm and the serum osmolality approaches 300 mOsm/L, the diagnosis of DI is confirmed. At this point, the patient should be given 5 U of an exogenous Pitressin subcutaneously. The extent of the DI can be determined by comparing the urine osmolality after Pitressin to the initial values. Increased urine osmolality by more than 67% indicates severe ADH deficiency. The increased levels of 6–67% is suggestive of partial deficiency.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a brain tumour. He undergoes an MRI, which proves the diagnosis of a brain tumour. With which of the following may brain tumours NOT present?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fever Brain tumours can present in many ways. They are often associated with seizures or focal neurological deficits. Pituitary and hypothalamic tumours can cause endocrine dysfunction. Some tumours tend to bleed and may present as a life-threatening intracerebral bleed. Visual loss can be caused by the tumour or present secondary to raised pressure and papilloedema.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient who presented with seizures and headaches underwent an MRI of the brain, which showed a temporal lobe tumour. What may be caused by dominant temporal lobe lesions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dysphasia Wernicke dysphasia occurs in lesions of the dominant temporal lobe.

Highyeild:

The temporal lobe structures are very involved in memory, speech and hearing. The temporal lobe is closely applied to the posterior frontal lobe at the Sylvian fissure, which carries the middle cerebral artery. Part of the optic radiation passes around the temporal lobe and can be affected by temporal lobe lesions. A contralateral superior quadrantanopia is seen in these cases. Temporal lobe lesions would not cause blindness in the ipsilateral eye or an ipsilateral hemiparesis – the motor cortex is in the posterior frontal lobe but supplies the contralateral limbs. The parietal lobe is sensory. Dominant parietal lobe lesions cause left–right disorientation, finger agnosia, acalculia and agraphia.
